snippet.title: Homo naledi, a new species of the genus Homo from the Dinaledi Chamber, South Africa

content.text: <italic>Homo naledi</italic> is a previously-unknown species of extinct hominin discovered within the Dinaledi Chamber of the Rising Star cave system, Cradle of Humankind, South Africa. This species is characterized by body mass and stature similar to small-bodied human populations but a small endocranial volume similar to australopiths. Cranial morphology of <italic>H. naledi</italic> is unique, but most similar to early <italic>Homo</italic> species including <italic>Homo erectus</italic>, <italic>Homo habilis</italic> or <italic>Homo rudolfensis</italic>. While primitive, the dentition is generally small and simple in occlusal morphology. <italic>H. naledi</italic> has humanlike manipulatory adaptations of the hand and wrist. It also exhibits a humanlike foot and lower limb. These humanlike aspects are contrasted in the postcrania with a more primitive or australopith-like trunk, shoulder, pelvis and proximal femur. Representing at least 15 individuals with most skeletal elements repeated multiple times, this is the largest assemblage of a single species of hominins yet discovered in Africa.
<bold>DOI:</bold> <ext-link ext-link-type="doi" href="10.7554/eLife.09560.001">http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.09560.001</ext-link>

article.impactStatement: A new hominin species has been unearthed in the Dinaledi Chamber of the Rising Star cave system in the largest assemblage of a single species of hominins yet discovered in Africa.

content.text: Modern humans, or <italic>Homo sapiens</italic>, are now the only living species in their genus. But as recently as 100,000 years ago, there were several other species that belonged to the genus <italic>Homo</italic>. Together with modern humans, these extinct human species, our immediate ancestors and their close relatives, are collectively referred to as ‘hominins’.

Now Berger et al. report the recent discovery of an extinct species from the genus <italic>Homo</italic> that was unearthed from deep underground in what has been named the Dinaledi Chamber, in the Rising Star cave system in South Africa. The species was named <italic>Homo naledi;</italic> ‘naledi’ means ‘star’ in Sotho (also called Sesotho), which is one of the languages spoken in South Africa.

The unearthed fossils were from at least 15 individuals and include multiple examples of most of the bones in the skeleton. Based on this wide range of specimens from a single site, Berger et al. describe <italic>Homo naledi</italic> as being similar in size and weight to a small modern human, with human-like hands and feet. Furthermore, while the skull had several unique features, it had a small braincase that was most similar in size to other early hominin species that lived between four million and two million years ago. <italic>Homo naledi</italic>'s ribcage, shoulders and pelvis also more closely resembled those of earlier hominin species than those of modern humans.

The <italic>Homo naledi</italic> fossils are the largest collection of a single species of hominin that has been discovered in Africa so far and, in a related study, Dirks et al. describe the setting and context for these fossils. However, since the age of the fossils remains unclear, one of the next challenges will be to date the remains to provide more information about the early evolution of humans and their close relatives.
<bold>DOI:</bold> <ext-link ext-link-type="doi" href="10.7554/eLife.09560.002">http://dx.doi.org/10.7554/eLife.09560.002</ext-link>

Fossil hominins were first recognized in the Dinaledi Chamber in the Rising Star cave system in October 2013. During a relatively short excavation, our team recovered an extensive collection of 1550 hominin specimens, representing nearly every element of the skeleton multiple times (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig1">Figure 1</xref>), including many complete elements and morphologically informative fragments, some in articulation, as well as smaller fragments many of which could be refit into more complete elements. The collection is a morphologically homogeneous sample that can be attributed to no previously-known hominin species. Here we describe this new species, <italic>Homo naledi</italic>. We have not defined <italic>H. naledi</italic> narrowly based on a single jaw or skull because the entire body of material has informed our understanding of its biology.

caption.text: The figure includes approximately all of the material incorporated in this diagnosis, including the holotype specimen, paratypes and referred material. These make up 737 partial or complete anatomical elements, many of which consist of several refitted specimens. Specimens not identified to element, such as non-diagnostic long bone or cranial fragments, and a subset of fragile specimens are not shown here. The ‘skeleton’ layout in the center of the photo is a composite of elements that represent multiple individuals. This view is foreshortened; the table upon which the bones are arranged is 120-cm wide for scale.

content.text: Order Primates LINNAEUS 1758
Suborder Anthropoidea MIVART 1864
Superfamily Hominoidea GRAY 1825
Family Hominidae GRAY 1825
Tribe Hominini GRAY 1825
Genus <italic>Homo</italic> LINNAEUS 1758

<italic>Homo naledi</italic> sp. nov. <ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="http://zoobank.org/References/00D1E81A-6E08-4A01-BD98-79A2CEAE2411">urn:lsid:zoobank.org:pub:00D1E81A-6E08-4A01-BD98-79A2CEAE2411</ext-link>
The word <italic>naledi</italic> means ‘star’ in the Sotho language and refers to the Dinaledi Chamber's location within the Rising Star cave system.

The Dinaledi chamber is located approximately 30 meters underground, within the Rising Star cave system at about 26°1′13′′ S; 27°42′43′′ E. The system lies within the Malmani dolomites, approximately 800 meters southwest of the well-known site of Swartkrans in the Cradle of Humankind World Heritage Site, Gauteng Province, South Africa.
The present sample of skeletal material from the Dinaledi Chamber was recovered during two field expeditions, in November 2013 and March 2014.

Six specimens from an ex situ context can be identified as bird bones, and few fragmentary rodent remains have been recovered within the excavation area. Neither of these faunal constituents can presently be associated with the hominin fossil collection (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib17">Dirks et al., 2015</xref>).

Aside from these limited faunal materials, the Dinaledi collection is entirely composed of hominin skeletal and dental remains. The collection so far comprises 1550 fossil hominin specimens, this number includes 1413 bone specimens and 137 isolated dental specimens; an additional 53 teeth are present in mandibular or maxillary bone specimens. Aside from the fragmentary rodent teeth, all dental crowns (n = 179) are hominin, recovered both from surface collection and excavation. Likewise, aside from the few bird elements, all morphologically informative bone specimens are clearly hominin. In all cases where elements are repeated in the sample, they are morphologically homogeneous, with variation consistent with body size and sex differences within a single population. These remains represent a minimum of 15 hominin individuals, as indicated by the repetition and presence of deciduous and adult dental elements.

The geological age of the fossils is not yet known. Excavations have thus far recovered hominin material from Unit 2 and Unit 3 in the chamber (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib17">Dirks et al., 2015</xref>). Surface-collected hominin material from the present top of Unit 3, which includes material derived from both Unit 2 and Unit 3, represents a minority of the assemblage, and is morphologically indistinguishable from material excavated from in situ within Unit 3. In addition to general morphological homogeneity including cranial shape, distinctive morphological configurations of all the recovered first metacarpals, femora, molars, lower premolars and lower canines, are identical in both surface-collected and excavated specimens (see Figure 14 later in the text). These include traits not found in any other hominin species yet described. These considerations strongly indicate that this material represents a single species, and not a commingled assemblage.

Dinaledi Hominin 1 (DH1) comprises the partial calvaria, partial maxilla, and nearly complete mandible of a presumed male individual, based on size and morphology within the sample (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig2">Figure 2</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). The holotype was recovered in situ during excavations within the Dinaledi Chamber in March of 2014, embedded in unconsolidated fine clay matrix (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib17">Dirks et al., 2015</xref>). The holotype is housed in the Evolutionary Studies Institute at the University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa.

content.text: Dinaledi Hominin 2 (DH2) is a partial calvaria that preserves parts of the frontal, left and right parietals, right temporal, and occipital (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3">Figure 3</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). Dinaledi Hominin 3 (DH3) is a partial calvaria of a presumed female individual that preserves parts of the frontal, left parietal, left temporal, and sphenoid (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig4">Figure 4</xref>, <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). Dinaledi Hominin 4 (DH4) is a partial calvaria that preserves parts of the right temporal, right parietal, and occipital (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3">Figure 3</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). Dinaledi Hominin 5 (DH5) is a partial calvaria that preserves part of the left temporal and occipital (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig3">Figure 3</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). U.W. 101-377 is a mandibular fragment that preserves dental anatomy in an unworn state; at present it cannot be definitively associated with any of these Dinaledi Hominin (DH) individuals, and indeed might represent another individual (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig5">Figure 5</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). These cranial specimens agree closely in nearly all morphological details where they overlap in areas preserved except those we interpret as related to sex.

content.text: Dinaledi hand 1 (H1) is a nearly complete (missing only the pisiform) right hand, found articulated in association, comprising specimens U.W. 101-1308 to −1311, −1318 to −1321, −1325 to −1329, −1351, −1464, and −1721 to −1732 (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig6">Figure 6</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). U.W. 101-1391 is a proximal right femur preserving part of the head, the neck, some of the lesser and greater trochanter, and the proximal shaft (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig7">Figure 7</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). U.W. 101-484 is a right tibial diaphysis missing only the proximal end (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig8">Figure 8</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>). Dinaledi foot 1 (F1) is a partial foot skeleton missing only the medial cuneiform and the phalanges of rays II–V. Foot 1 is composed of specimens U.W. 101-1322, −1417 to −1419, −1439, −1443, −1456 to −1458, −1551, −1553, −1562, and −1698 (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig9">Figure 9</xref>; <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>).

caption.text: Palmar view on left; dorsal view on right. This hand was discovered in articulation and all bones are represented except for the pisiform. The proportions of digits are humanlike and visually apparent, as are the expanded distal apical tufts on all digits, the robust pollical ray, and the unique first metacarpal morphology.

(<bold>A</bold>) Medial view; (<bold>B</bold>) posterior view; (<bold>C</bold>) lateral view; (<bold>D</bold>) anterior view. The femur neck is relatively long and anteroposteriorly compressed. The anteversion of the neck is evident in medial view. Scale bar = 2 cm.
(<bold>A</bold>) Anterior view; (<bold>B</bold>) medial view; (<bold>C</bold>) posterior view; (<bold>D</bold>) lateral view. The tibiae are notably slender for their length. Scale bar = 10 cm.

content.text: Referred material is also listed in <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref>. We refer to <italic>H. naledi</italic> all hominin material from the Dinaledi collection that can be identified to element; in total, the holotypes, paratypes and referred material comprise 737 partial or complete anatomical elements.

Specimen numbers in the collection are assigned at the point of excavation. Later laboratory analyses allowed us to refit specimens into more complete elements, which we have used as units of anatomical study. Here we refer to refitted elements by only a single specimen number; either the number of the most constitutive specimen, or the first diagnostic part to be discovered. DH designations are reserved for clearly associated individuals; at this time these are limited to the five partial crania designated above. Future excavation and analyses will certainly uncover more refits among specimens. As refits are found, all numbers assigned to refitted elements will remain stable, and all numbers in <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD1-data">Supplementary file 1</xref> will be retained.

The collection is morphologically homogeneous in all duplicated elements, except for those anatomical features that normally reflect body size or sex differences in other primate taxa. Therefore, although we refer to the holotype and the paratypes for differential diagnoses; the section describing the overall anatomy encompasses all morphologically informative specimens.

This comprehensive differential diagnosis is based upon cranial, dental and postcranial characters. The hypodigms used for other species are detailed in the ‘Materials and methods’. We examined original specimens for most species, except where indicated in the ‘Materials and methods’; when we relied on other sources for anatomical observations we indicate this. A summary of traits of <italic>H. naledi</italic> in comparison to other species is presented in <xref ref-type="supplementary-material" rid="SD2-data">Supplementary file 2</xref>. Comparative cranial and mandibular measures are presented in <xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl1">Table 1</xref>, and comparative dental measures are provided in <xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl2">Table 2</xref>.

content.title: Cranium, mandible, and dentition (DH1, DH2, DH3, DH4, DH5, U.W. 101-377)

content.text: The cranium of <italic>H. naledi</italic> does not have the well-developed crest patterns that characterize <italic>Australopithecus garhi</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib5">Asfaw et al., 1999</xref>) and species of the genus <italic>Paranthropus</italic>, nor the derived facial morphology seen in the latter genus. The mandible of <italic>H. naledi</italic> is notably more gracile than those of <italic>Paranthropus</italic>. Although maxillary and mandibular incisors and canines of <italic>H. naledi</italic> overlap in size with those of <italic>Paranthropus</italic>, the post-canine teeth are notably smaller than those of <italic>Paranthropus</italic> and <italic>Au. garhi</italic>, with mandibular molars that are buccolingually narrow.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from <italic>Australopithecus afarensis</italic> and <italic>Australopithecus africanus</italic> in having a pentagonal-shaped cranial vault in posterior view, sagittal keeling, widely spaced temporal lines, an angular torus, a deep and narrow digastric fossa, an external occipital protuberance, an anteriorly positioned root of the zygomatic process of the maxilla, a broad palate, and a small canine jugum lacking anterior pillars. The anterior and lateral vault of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from <italic>Au. afarensis</italic> and <italic>Au. africanus</italic> in exhibiting only slight post-orbital constriction, frontal bossing, a well-developed supraorbital torus with a well-defined supratoral sulcus, temporal lines that are positioned on the posterior rather than the superior aspect of the supraorbital torus, a root of the zygomatic process of the temporal that is angled downwards approximately 30° relative to the Frankfort Horizontal (FH) and which begins its lateral expansion above the mandibular fossa rather than the EAM, a mandibular fossa that is positioned medial to the wall of the temporal squame, a small postglenoid process that contacts the tympanic, a coronally oriented petrous, and a small and obliquely oriented EAM. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandible exhibits a more gracile symphysis and corpus, a more vertically inclined symphysis, a slight mandibular incurvation delineating a faint mental trigon, and a steeply inclined posterior face of the mandibular symphysis without a post incisive planum. The incisors of <italic>H. naledi</italic> overlap in size with some specimens of <italic>Au. africanus</italic>, though the canines and post-canine dentition are notably smaller, with relatively narrow buccolingual dimensions of the mandibular molars. The maxillary I<sup>1</sup> lacks a median lingual ridge and exhibits a broad and uninflated lingual cervical prominence, the lingual mesial and distal marginal ridges do not merge onto the cervical prominence in the maxillary I<sup>2</sup>, the mandibular canine exhibits only a weak lingual median ridge and a broad and uninflated lingual cervical prominence, and the buccal grooves on the maxillary premolars are only weakly developed. <italic>H. naledi</italic> exhibits a small and isolated Carabelli's feature in the maxillary molars, unlike the more prominent and extensive Carabelli's feature of <italic>Australopithecus</italic>. Moreover, the <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandibular molars possess small, mesiobuccally restricted protostylids that do not intersect the buccal groove, differing from the typically enlarged, centrally positioned protostylids that intersect the buccal groove in <italic>Australopithecus</italic>.

The cranium of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from <italic>Australopithecus sediba</italic> (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib6">Berger et al., 2010</xref>) in exhibiting sagittal keeling, a more pronounced supraorbital torus and supratoral sulcus, a weakly arched supraorbital contour with rounded lateral corners, an angular torus, a well-defined supramastoid crest, a curved superior margin of the temporal squama, a root of the zygomatic process of the temporal that is angled downwards approximately 30° relative to FH, a flattened nasoalveolar clivus, weak canine juga, an anteriorly positioned root of the zygomatic process of the maxilla, and a relatively broad palate that is anteriorly shallow. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandible (DH1) has a mental foramen positioned superiorly on the corpus that opens posteriorly, unlike the mid-corpus height, more laterally opening mental foramen of <italic>Au. sediba</italic>. The maxillary and mandibular teeth of <italic>H. naledi</italic> are smaller than those of <italic>Au. sediba</italic>, with mandibular molars that are buccolingually narrow. The lingual mesial and distal marginal ridges do not merge onto the cervical prominence in the maxillary I<sup>2</sup>, the paracone of the maxillary P<sup>3</sup> is equal in size to the protocone, the protoconid and metaconid of the mandibular molars are equally mesially positioned, and the lingual cusps of the molars are positioned at the occlusobuccal margin while the buccal cusps are positioned slightly lingual to the occlusobuccal margin. Also, <italic>Au. sediba</italic> shares with other australopiths a protostylid that is centrally located and which intersects the buccal groove of the lower molars, unlike the small and mesiobuccally restricted protostylid that does not intersect the buccal groove in <italic>H. naledi</italic>.

The cranium of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from <italic>Homo habilis</italic> in exhibiting sagittal keeling, a weakly arched supraorbital contour, temporal lines that are positioned on the posterior rather than the superior aspect of the supraorbital torus, an angular torus, an occipital torus, only slight post-orbital constriction, a curved superior margin of the temporal squama, a suprameatal spine, a weak crista petrosa, a prominent Eustachian process, a small EAM, weak canine juga, and an anteriorly positioned root of the zygomatic process of the maxilla. Mandibles attributed to <italic>H. habilis</italic> show a weakly inclined, shelf-like post incisive planum with a variably developed superior transverse torus, unlike the steeply inclined posterior face of the mandibular symphysis of <italic>H. naledi</italic>, which lacks both a post incisive planum or superior transverse torus. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandible (DH1) has a mental foramen positioned superiorly on the corpus that opens posteriorly, while the mental foramen of <italic>H. habilis</italic> is at mid-corpus height and opens more laterally. The maxillary and mandibular dentitions of DH1 are smaller than typical for <italic>H. habilis</italic>. The mandibular P<sub>3</sub> of <italic>H. naledi</italic> is more molarized and lacks the occlusal simplification seen in <italic>H. habilis</italic>; it has a symmetrical occlusal outline, and multiple roots (two roots: mesiobuccal and distal) not seen in <italic>H. habilis</italic>. The molars of <italic>H. naledi</italic> lack crenulation, secondary fissures, and supernumerary cusps that are common to <italic>H. habilis</italic>. The protoconid and metaconid of the mandibular molars are equally mesially positioned.

The cranium of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from <italic>Homo rudolfensis</italic> by its smaller cranial capacity, and by exhibiting frontal bossing, a post-bregmatic depression, sagittal keeling, a well-developed supraorbital torus delineated by a distinct supratoral sulcus, temporal lines that are positioned on the posterior rather than the superior aspect of the supraorbital torus, an occipital torus, an external occipital protuberance, only slight post-orbital constriction, a small postglenoid process, a weak crista petrosa, a laterally inflated mastoid process, a canine fossa, incisors that project anteriorly beyond the bi-canine line, and a shallow anterior palate. As in <italic>H. habilis</italic>, mandibles attributed to <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic> show a weakly inclined, shelf-like post incisive planum with a variably developed superior transverse torus, unlike the steeply inclined posterior face of the mandibular symphysis of DH1, the latter of which lacks either a post incisive planum or superior transverse torus. The mandibular symphysis and corpus of <italic>H. naledi</italic> are more gracile than those attributed to <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic>, and the <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandible (DH1) has a mental foramen positioned superiorly on the corpus that opens posteriorly, unlike the mid-corpus height, more laterally opening mental foramen of <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic>. The maxillary and mandibular dentition of <italic>H. naledi</italic> is smaller than that of most specimens of <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic>, with only KNM-ER 60000 and KNM-ER 62000 appearing similar in size for some teeth (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib41">Leakey et al., 2012</xref>). The molars of <italic>H. naledi</italic> lack crenulation, secondary fissures, or supernumerary cusps common in <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic>. The buccal grooves of the maxillary premolars are weak in <italic>H. naledi</italic>, and the protoconid and metaconid of the mandibular molars are equally mesially positioned.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> lacks the typically distinctive long and low cranial vault of <italic>Homo erectus</italic>, as well as the metopic keeling that is typically present in the latter species. <italic>H. naledi</italic> also differs from <italic>H. erectus</italic> in having a distinct external occipital protuberance in addition to the tuberculum linearum, a laterally inflated mastoid process, a flat and squared nasoalveolar clivus, and an anteriorly shallow palate. The parasagittal keeling that is present between bregma and lambda in <italic>H. naledi</italic> (DH1 and DH3) is less marked than often occurs in <italic>H. erectus</italic>, including in small specimens such as KNM-ER 42700 and the Dmanisi cranial sample. Also unlike most specimens of <italic>H. erectus</italic>, <italic>H. naledi</italic> has a small vaginal process, a weak crista petrosa, a marked Eustachian process, and a small EAM. The mandible of <italic>H. erectus</italic> shows a moderately inclined, shelf-like post incisive planum terminating in a variably developed superior transverse torus, differing from the steeply inclined posterior face of the <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandibular symphysis, which lacks both a post incisive planum or a superior transverse torus. The mental foramen is positioned superiorly and opens posteriorly in DH1, unlike the mid-corpus height, more laterally opening mental foramen of <italic>H. erectus</italic>. The maxillary and mandibular incisors and canines of <italic>H. naledi</italic> are smaller than typical of <italic>H. erectus</italic>. The mandibular P<sub>3</sub> of <italic>H. naledi</italic> is more molarized and lacks the occlusal simplification seen in <italic>H. erectus</italic>, they reveal a symmetrical occlusal outline, and multiple roots (2R: MB+D) not typically seen in <italic>H. erectus</italic>. Furthermore, the molars of <italic>H. naledi</italic> lack crenulation, secondary fissures, or supernumerary cusps common in <italic>H. erectus</italic>.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> lacks the reduced cranial height of <italic>Homo floresiensis</italic>, and displays a marked angular torus and parasagittal keeling between bregma and lambda that is absent in the latter species. <italic>H. naledi</italic> further has a flat and squared nasoalveolar clivus, unlike the pronounced maxillary canine juga and prominent pillars of <italic>H. floresiensis</italic>. The mandible of <italic>H. floresiensis</italic> shows a posteriorly inclined post incisive planum with superior and inferior transverse tori, differing from the steeply inclined posterior face of the <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandibular symphysis, which lacks both a post incisive planum or a superior transverse torus. Dentally, <italic>H. naledi</italic> is distinguishable from <italic>H. floresiensis</italic> by the mesiodistal elongation and extensive talonid of the mandibular P<sub>4</sub>, and the lack of Tomes' root on the mandibular premolars. The molar size gradient of <italic>H. naledi</italic> follows the M1 < M2 < M3 pattern, unlike the M3 < M2 < M1 pattern in <italic>H. floresiensis</italic>, and the mandibular molars are relatively mesiodistally long and buccolingually narrow compared to those of <italic>H. floresiensis</italic>.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from Middle Pleistocene (MP) and Late Pleistocene (LP) <italic>Homo</italic> (here we include specimens sometimes attributed to the putative Early Pleistocene taxon <italic>Homo antecessor</italic>, and MP <italic>Homo heidelbergensis</italic>, <italic>Homo rhodesiensis</italic>, as well as archaic <italic>Homo sapiens</italic> and Neandertals) in exhibiting a smaller cranial capacity. <italic>H. naledi</italic> has its maximum cranial width in the supramastoid region, rather than in the parietal region. It has a clearly defined canine fossa (similar to <italic>H. antecessor</italic>), a shallow anterior palate, and a flat and a squared nasoalveolar clivus. <italic>H. naledi</italic> lacks the bilaterally arched and vertically thickened supraorbital tori found in MP and LP <italic>Homo</italic>. <italic>H. naledi</italic> also differs in exhibiting a root of the zygomatic process of the temporal that is angled downwards approximately 30° relative to FH, a projecting entoglenoid process, a weak vaginal process, a weak crista petrosa, a prominent Eustachian process, a laterally inflated mastoid process, and a small EAM. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandible tends to be more gracile than specimens of MP <italic>Homo</italic>. The mandibular canine retains a distinct accessory distal cuspulid not seen in MP and LP <italic>Homo</italic>. Molar cuspal proportions for <italic>H. naledi</italic> do not show the derived reduction of the entoconid and hypoconid that characterizes MP and LP <italic>Homo</italic>. The mandibular M<sub>3</sub> is not reduced in DH1, thus revealing an increasing molar size gradient that contrasts with reduction of the M<sub>3</sub> in MP and LP <italic>Homo</italic>.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from <italic>H. sapiens</italic> in exhibiting small cranial capacity, a well-defined supraorbital torus and supratoral sulcus, a root of the zygomatic process of the temporal that is angled downwards approximately 30° relative to FH, a large and laterally inflated mastoid with well-developed supramastoid crest, an angular torus, a small vaginal process, a weak crista petrosa, a prominent Eustachian process, a small EAM, a flat and squared nasoalveolar clivus, and a more posteriorly positioned incisive foramen. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> mandible shows a weaker, less well-defined mentum osseum than <italic>H. sapiens</italic>, as well as a slight inferior transverse torus that is absent in humans. The mental foramen is positioned superiorly in <italic>H. naledi</italic>, unlike the mid-corpus height mental foramen of <italic>H. sapiens</italic>. The mandibular canine possesses a distinct accessory distal cuspulid not seen in <italic>H. sapiens</italic>. Molar cuspal proportions for <italic>H. naledi</italic> do not show the derived reduction of the entoconid and hypoconid that characterizes <italic>H. sapiens</italic>. The mandibular M<sub>3</sub> is not reduced in <italic>H. naledi</italic>, thus revealing an increasing molar size gradient that contrasts with reduction of the M<sub>3</sub> in <italic>H. sapiens</italic>.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> possesses a combination of primitive and derived features not seen in the hand of any other hominin. H1 is differentiated from the estimated intrinsic hand proportions of <italic>Au. afarensis</italic> in having a relatively long thumb ((Mc1 + PP1)/(Mc3 + PP3 + IP3)) (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib50">Rolian and Gordon, 2013</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib2">Almécija and Alba, 2014</xref>). It is further distinguished from <italic>Au. afarensis</italic>, <italic>Au. africanus,</italic> and <italic>Au. sediba</italic> in having a well-developed crest for both the <italic>opponens pollicis</italic> and first dorsal <italic>interosseous</italic> muscles, a trapezium-scaphoid joint that extends onto the scaphoid tubercle, a relatively large and more palmarly-positioned capitate-trapezoid joint, and/or a saddle-shaped Mc5-hamate joint. <italic>H. naledi</italic> also differs from <italic>Au. sediba</italic> in that it lacks mediolaterally narrow Mc2-5 shafts (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib39">Kivell et al., 2011</xref>). Manual morphology of <italic>Au. garhi</italic> is currently unknown.

H1 is distinguished from <italic>H. habilis</italic> in having a deep proximal palmar fossa with a well-developed ridge distally for the insertion of the <italic>flexor pollicis longus</italic> muscle on the first distal phalanx, and a more proximodistally oriented trapezium-second metacarpal joint. It also differs from both <italic>H. habilis</italic> and <italic>H. floresiensis</italic> by having a relatively large trapezium-scaphoid joint that extends onto the scaphoid tubercle, and from <italic>H. floresiensis</italic> in having a boot-shaped trapezoid with an expanded palmar surface, and a relatively large and more palmarly-positioned capitate-trapezoid joint (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib65">Tocheri et al., 2005</xref>, <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib64">2007</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib47">Orr et al., 2013</xref>).

H1 is dissimilar to hand remains attributed to <italic>Paranthropus robustus</italic>/early <italic>Homo</italic> from Swartkrans (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib57">Susman, 1988</xref>; <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib58">Susman et al., 2001</xref>) in having a relatively small Mc1 base and proximal articular facet, a saddle-shaped Mc5-hamate joint, and more curved proximal and intermediate phalanges of ray 2–5.

Manual morphology of <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic> is currently unknown, and that of <italic>H. erectus</italic> is largely unknown. Still, H1 differs from a third metacarpal attributed to <italic>H. erectus s. l.</italic>, as well as from <italic>Homo neanderthalensis</italic> and <italic>H. sapiens</italic> by lacking a styloid process (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib68">Ward et al., 2013</xref>).

H1 is further distinguished from <italic>H. neanderthalensis</italic> and <italic>H. sapiens</italic> by its relatively small facets for the Mc1 and scaphoid on the trapezium, its low angle between the Mc2 and Mc3 facets on the capitate, and by its long and curved proximal and intermediate phalanges on rays 2–5.

H1 is differentiated from all known hominins in having a Mc1 that combines a mediolaterally narrow proximal end and articular facet with a mediolaterally wide distal shaft and head, a dorsopalmarly flat and strongly asymmetric (with an enlarged palmar-lateral protuberance) Mc1 head, and the combination of an overall later <italic>Homo</italic>-like carpal morphology combined with proximal and intermediate phalanges that are more curved than most australopiths. H1 also differs from all other known hominins except <italic>H. neanderthalensis</italic> in having non-pollical distal phalanges with mediolaterally broad apical tufts (relative to length).

The femur of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from those of all other known hominins in its possession of two well-defined, mediolaterally-running pillars in the femoral neck. The pillars run along the superoanterior and inferoposterior margins of the neck and define a distinct sulcus along its superior aspect.

The tibia of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from those of all other known hominins in its possession of a distinct tubercle for the pes anserinus tendon. The tibia differs from other hominins except <italic>H. habilis, H. floresiensis</italic>, and (variably) <italic>H. sapiens</italic> in its possession of a rounded anterior border.

The foot of <italic>H. naledi</italic> differs from the pedal remains of <italic>Au. afarensis, Au. africanus,</italic> and <italic>Au. sediba</italic> in having a calcaneus with a weakly developed peroneal trochlea. F1 also differs from <italic>Au. afarensis</italic> in having a higher orientation of the calcaneal sustentaculum tali. F1 can be further distinguished from pedal remains attributed to <italic>Au. africanus</italic> in having a higher talar head and neck torsion, a narrower Mt1 base, a dorsally expanded Mt1 head, and greater proximolateral to distomedial orientation of the lateral metatarsals. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> foot can be further differentiated from the foot of <italic>Au. sediba</italic> in having a proximodistally flatter talar trochlea, a flat subtalar joint, a diagonally oriented retrotrochlear eminence and a plantar position of the lateral plantar process of the calcaneous, and dorsoplantarly flat articular surface for the cuboid on the Mt4 (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib72">Zipfel et al., 2011</xref>). Pedal remains of <italic>Au. garhi</italic> are currently unknown, and those of <italic>P. robustus</italic> are too poorly known to allow for comparison.

The <italic>H. naledi</italic> foot can be distinguished from the foot of <italic>H. habilis</italic> by the presence of a flatter, non-sloping trochlea with equally elevated medial and lateral margins, a narrower Mt1 base, greater proximolateral to distomedial orientation of the lateral metatarsals, and a metatarsal robusticity ratio of 1 > 5 > 4 > 3 > 2. Pedal morphology in <italic>H. rudolfensis</italic> is currently unknown, and that of <italic>H. erectus</italic> is too poorly known to allow for comparison. The <italic>H. naledi</italic> foot can be distinguished from the foot of <italic>H. floresiensis</italic> by a longer hallux and shorter second through fifth metacarpals relative to hindfoot length, and higher torsion of the talar head and neck.

The foot of <italic>H. naledi</italic> can be distinguished from the foot of <italic>H. sapiens</italic> only by its flatter lateral and medial malleolar facets on the talus, its low angle of plantar declination of the talar head, its lower orientation of the calcaneal sustentaculum tali, and its gracile calcaneal tuber.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> exhibits anatomical features shared with <italic>Australopithecus</italic>, other features shared with <italic>Homo</italic>, with several features not otherwise known in any hominin species. This anatomical mosaic is reflected in different regions of the skeleton. The morphology of the cranium, mandible, and dentition is mostly consistent with the genus <italic>Homo</italic>, but the brain size of <italic>H. naledi</italic> is within the range of <italic>Australopithecus</italic>. The lower limb is largely <italic>Homo</italic>-like, and the foot and ankle are particularly human in their configuration, but the pelvis appears to be flared markedly like that of <italic>Au. afarensis</italic>. The wrists, fingertips, and proportions of the fingers are shared mainly with <italic>Homo</italic>, but the proximal and intermediate manual phalanges are markedly curved, even to a greater degree than in any <italic>Australopithecus</italic>. The shoulders are configured largely like those of australopiths. The vertebrae are most similar to Pleistocene members of the genus <italic>Homo</italic>, whereas the ribcage is wide distally like <italic>Au. afarensis</italic>.

<italic>H. naledi</italic> has a range of body mass similar to small-bodied modern human populations, and is similar in estimated stature to both small-bodied humans and the largest known australopiths. We estimated body mass from eight femoral specimens for which subtrochanteric diameters can be measured (‘Materials and methods’), with results ranging between 39.7 kg and 55.8 kg (<xref ref-type="table" rid="tbl3">Table 3</xref>). No femur specimen is sufficiently complete to measure femur length accurately, but the U.W. 101-484 tibia preserves nearly its complete length, allowing a tibia length estimate of 325 mm (<xref ref-type="fig" rid="fig10">Figure 10</xref>). Estimates for the stature of this individual based on African human population samples range between 144.5 and 147.8 mm. Again, this stature estimate is similar to small-bodied modern human populations. It is within the range estimated for Dmanisi postcranial elements (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib43">Lordkipanidze et al., 2007</xref>), and slightly smaller than estimated for early <italic>Homo</italic> femoral specimens KNM-ER 1472 and KNM-ER 1481. Some large australopiths also had long tibiae and presumably comparably tall statures, as evidenced by the KSD-VP 1/1 skeleton from Woranso-Mille (<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="bib27">Haile-Selassie et al., 2010</xref>).
